unittitle.altrender: Agnes Kun and Antal Hidas Papers,

did.unittitle: Agnes Kun and Antal Hidas Papers,

physdesc.extent: 4 linear ft. (5 archival document boxes and 1 flat box).

repository.corpname: Columbia University.Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers comprise the correspondence of Agnes Kun (1915-1990), translator, and Antal Hidas (1899-1980), Hungarian poet, with prominent Russian poets and writers; Antal Hidas's memoirs; and manuscripts of translations from Hungarian and original poetry by famous Russian authors.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: Agnes Kun (January 21, 1915-October 19, 1990), translator and editor, daughter of Bela Kun, wife of Hungarian poet Antal Hidas (12.18.1899-01.22.1980), who in the 1920s immigrated to the Soviet Union. Both Agnes Kun and Antal Hidas went through the Gulag. Kun and Hidas became the main Soviet experts on Hungarian literature. It was under their leadership that many collections of Hungarian poetry were translated and published in the USSR in the 1950s. They returned to Hungary in 1959.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of significant correspondence with prominent Russian poets and writers and manuscripts of translations from Hungarian and original poetry by famous Russian authors. Among authors whose letters and manuscripts are represented in the collection are: Margarita Aliger, Lili Brik, Kornei Chukovskii, Aleksandr Fadeev, Vera Inber, Lev Kopelev, Leonid Martynov, Boris Pasternak, Boris Polevoi, David Samoilov, Boris Slutskii, Nikolai Tikhonov, Nikolai Zabolotskii, and many others. Oversize materials stored in BAR Flat Box #5.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This collection is organized in four series.
Series I: Correspondence, 1941-1982, undated
Series II: Writings, 1940-1987, undated
Subseries II.1: Antal Hidas's Writings, 1943-1968, undated
Subseries II.2: Writings by Others, 1940-1987, undated
Series III: Printed Materials, 1917, 1940, undated
Series IV: Third Parties Materials, 1915-1947

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of specific item; Date (if known); Agnes Kun and Antal Hidas Papers; Box and Folder; Bakhmeteff Archive, Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Finding aid written by Katia Shraga November 2011.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Single photocopies may be made for research purposes. Permission to publish material from the collection must be requested from the Curator of the Bakhmeteff Archive. The RBML approves permission to publish that which it physically owns; the responsibility to secure copyright permission rests with the patron.

otherfindaid.p: Finding aid in repository; folder level control.

scopecontent.p: The series consists mainly of letters to Agnes Kun and Antal Hidas from prominent Russian authors.

scopecontent.p: The series comprises mainly manuscripts of Antal Hidas and famous Russian poets. Organized in two Subseries.

did.unittitle: Subseries II.1: Antal Hidas's Writings, 1943-1968, undated

scopecontent.p: Contains typescript with holograph corrections of Hidas's memoirs. The memoirs are compilation of Hidas's essays written in various years. Arranged according to page numeration.

did.physdesc: (carbon copy of typescript with holograph corrections)>

"Dvorik ty moi dvorik: Bela Bartok v Moskve," undated

scopecontent.p: (about L. Martynov)
(about Mate Zalka)

did.unittitle: Subseries II.2: Writings by Others, 1940-1987, undated

scopecontent.p: The Subseries contains mainly holograph manuscript and typescripts of original poetry and translations by famous Russian poets, such as Boris Pasternak, Nikolai Chukovskii, Mariia Petrovykh, Semen Kirsanov, Boris Slutskii, David Samoilov, Leonid Pervomaiskii, Leonid Martynov, Vsevolod Rozhdestvenskii, Andrei Voznesenskii, Nikolai Zabolotskii. Zabolotskii's writings include a bound typed manuscript "Stolbtsy i poemy. Stikhotvoreniia." N. Zabolotskii compiled this book of his poems in 1958 and considered it a complete edition of his poetry. This handmade book is one of seven copies. The Subseries also includes memoirs of Ivan Borisov and Ferenc Jancsik, and Semen Budennyi's essay on Bela Kun. There is also a photograph of Ivan Borisov, which remains with his memoirs, and three drawings of Leonid Martynov, which are stored along with his writings.
(samizdat typescript received from A. Akhmatova)

scopecontent.p: The Series includes are edition of Maiakovskii's Liubliu (which is claimed to be from Lili Brik's personal library; Martynov' Poemy with inscription to Agnes Kun and Antal Hidas; Communist and Soviet propaganda pamphlets, 1918-1944; and nine issues of the newspaper Edinstvo of 1917. The newspapers are stored in BAR Flat box #5. All items of this series are cataloged in CLIO.
(from Lili Brik's personal library)
